fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A morphism x\xhookrightarrow {f} y is a monomorphism if for any pair of parallel arrows z\overset {g,h}{\rightrightarrows } x, fg = fh implies g = h.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Category theory in context

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Suitable for advanced undergraduates and graduate students in mathematics, the text provides tools for understanding and attacking difficult problems in algebra, number theory, algebraic geometry, and algebraic topology. Drawing upon a broad range of mathematical examples from the categorical perspective, the author illustrates how the concepts and constructions of category theory arise from and illuminate more basic mathematical ideas. Prerequisites are limited to familiarity with some basic set theory and logic.

fr:title.text: Monos and epis in preabelian categories

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Monos and epis in preabelian categories

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given that f is a mono, and noting that the zero map z\xrightarrow {0} x equalizes f and x\xrightarrow {0} y, any other map x\to z which equalizes these maps must also be 0. The zero map factors uniquely through the object 0, so that 0 satisfies the universal property of the kernel.
The coimage is now the cokernel of the kernel, hence the cokernel of the zero map 0\to x, hence the coequalizer of the zero map with itself, hence just the identity at x.
Exactness follows from the definition of an exact sequence.
Regular categories have a (regular epi, mono) factorization system.
An epimorphism is regular if it is a coequalizer. Dually, a monomorphism is regular if it is an equalizer.
Every regular epimorphism is strong.

An epimorphism is strong if it has the (necessarily strong) left lifting property against any monomorphism; dually, a monomorphism is strong if it has the right lifting property against any epimorphism.
To show the first two, note that monos are limits and limits are created in Set.

To show the kernel result, note that if f is injective, then the kernel is automatically trivial, whereas if f has trivial kernel, then for any x, y\in G with f(x) = f(y), f(xy^{-1}) = e, so xy^{-1}\in \ker (f), meaning xy^{-1} = e, and now x = y.
A group action of G on A is faithful if the map G\to S_A is a monomorphism.

A relation in a category C on objects x and y is a monormorphism into the product x\times y; more generally, it consists of a pair of of jointly monic arrows r\xhookrightarrow {r_1} x, r\xhookrightarrow {r_2} y so that for any pair of parallel arrows z\xhookrightarrow {f, g} r, r_1g = r_1h and r_2g = r_2h implies g = h.
Dually, f is epic if and only if its cokernel pair is 1_y.

Suppose f is monic; then for any pair of maps z\overset {g, h}{\rightrightarrows } x such that fg = fh, g = h, so that g satisfies the universal property of the pullback; it is the only map which does so, again since f is monic.
Conversely, suppose the square is a pullback; then given maps z\xrightarrow {g, h} x such that fg = fh, both g and h witness the universal property, so uniqueness implies g = h.

fr:title.text: Faithful functors reflect monos and epis

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Faithful functors reflect monos and epis

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Faithful functors reflect monomorphisms and epimorphisms.

We show the result for monos: let C\xrightarrow {F} D be faithful and Fx\xrightarrow {Ff} Fy a mono in D. Then given z\overset {g,h}{\rightrightarrows } x in C such that fg = fh, we have by functoriality that FfFg = FfFh, so since Ff is a mono, we have Fg = Fh. Now by faithfulness of F, g = h, as desired.
To conclude for epis, note that the opposite functor C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {F^\text {op}}D^\text {op} remains faithful, so the result for monos dualizes.
Sections are monomorphisms. Dually, retracts are epimorphisms.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Let x\xrightarrow {s} y be a section with retract y\xrightarrow {r} s. Let z\overset {f, g}{\rightrightarrows } x be a parallel pair such that sf = sg. Then f = 1_xf = rsf = rsg = 1_xg = g, as desired.

fr:title.text: Properties of adjoint functors relate to those of their (co)units

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of adjoint functors relate to those of their (co)units

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Dually, pushouts preserve epimorphisms.
An injection is a monomorhpism in Set. Explicitly, a map A\xrightarrow {f} B is injective if, for every x,y\in A, f(x)=f(y) implies x=y.
A morphism x\xrightarrow {s}y is a section, pre-inverse, or split monomorphism if there exists a morphism y\xrightarrow {r}x such that rs = 1_x.
A category C consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: a collection of objects, overloadingly also called C;
for each pair of objects x,y\in C, a collection of morphisms C(x, y);
for each object x\in C, a designated identity morphism x\xrightarrow {1_x} x;
for each pair of morphisms x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g} z, a designated composite morphism x\xrightarrow {gf} z.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data must satisfy the following axioms:

fr:ul.fr:li: unitality: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y, 1_yf = f = f1_x;
associativity: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g}z\xrightarrow {h}w, h(gf) = (hg)f.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In other words, the following diagrams must commute:
